reviewText: Very well written sitcom revolves around the Heck family from Orson Indiana, in the "middle" of the country. The Middle rings true with  characters and situations that most families with kids experience. Patricia Heaton is once again a strong female lead as Frankie Heck, a harried housewife and mother who also works selling cars at "Orson's last remaining car dealership." Neil Flynn shines as the father, Mike Heck, who works at the local quarry and who thinks "sports" is the answer to many of the kids problems, especially Axl, who is a gifted athlete and youngest son Brick, who is totally obsessed with books and fonts. Brick has to attend special socialization classes with an assorted group of quirky kids like himself. The daughter Sue Heck is deftly played by Eden Sher. Sue is the eternal optimist, albeit a geeky one, who frequently spars with Axl. The supporting players are all  excellent in their roles as Heck neighbors, friends, and relatives. I like Season 1 &2 for the character of Bob, Frankie's friend and co-worker who longs to belong to a family like the Hecks and is perfectly played by Chris Kattan. Kattan is seen less and less in season 3 and is gone after the first episode in Season 4. There is no explanation why this happens, and after being fired from the dealership, we lose the great comedy delivered by Kattan and the rest of the supporting players in the Elhert car dealership. Seasons 4&5 are weaker without Kattan. A good show that is still enjoyable but that misses the chemisty found among all the cast in the first three seasons.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Everyone in our family LOVED "The Middle" as soon as we saw it.  Maybe it's because we lived in Indiana for 10 years...the setting for the show.  Maybe it's because there's someone for anyone to associate with on the cast - the well-meaning but severely overworked and stressed mom, the hardworking and largely clueless yet effective dad, the egocentric HS aged son, the socially invisible JHS daughter who tries her hardest to be include by trying out for everything, but making nothing, and the brilliant, yet socially challenged elementary aged younger son who proves again and again that the act of giving someone a cool name, "Brick" in this case, does not guarantee that they will be at all cool.I had the brilliant idea of giving Seasons 1 and 2 of The Middle to my wife for Valentine's earlier this year... and it was a solid gold hit!  My wife was thrilled nearly beyond words, and her friends were deeply jealous that all they got was a card and flowers.  Take that other husbands!  Ha!  Anyway, this show is a total hit at our house.  In fact, whenever we can we load up our dinner, haul it over by the TV and watch an episode...just one per evening...of The Middle while we eat.  My wife rations the episodes out so they last longer...so we can savor them and look forward to them.Just in case you don't know about The Middle - it's a show about the most average family you can imagine living the most ordinary life you can imagine in the most ordinary place you can imagine.  Frankei and Mike, the parents, struggle to make ends meet, Axl, the HS-age jock son, plays the teenager role brilliantly, usually painfully so, Sue is the sweet forgotten middle child who is self-sufficient and self-reliant, and Brick is the youngest, a child who loves NOTHING more than books and reading...to the exclusion of the world around him.5 stars...and may the series run as long as the magic is there.
summary: A super-fantastic TV show...we hope they keep rolling them out as long as they can

reviewText: This is a sit-com series that grows on you. The true measure of the quality of a TV family is the degree in which it draws the viewer into feeling part of that family. I have to say my family was never this fun, and I would be delighted to share their experiences in real life. The mother is somewhat over the top, but we'll give her a pass since she cares so much. The program creators have succeeded in plowing new sit-com ground. Each member is so different from each other and yet in the end mesh into caring siblings, if not without a defiant sense of individuality.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The little kid on this show is just wonderful, Brick.  I am not a parent myself but he has utterly captivated me.  He is an odd kid, doesn't fit into anyone's niche but that is what makes him irresistible. So even if the rest of this show was a disaster, I doubt I could give up seeing Brick each week. But the rest is not a disaster, just the opposite in fact.  Patricia Heaton plays a middle class mother in Indiana holding it all together despite being the Mom in a family of true eccentrics. Between juggling her full duties as mother of three and wife, she also works at a car dealership where she is the absolute worst salesperson. Even if the economy were booming, I could not see her zooming ahead in this field. The other two kids are teenagers.  The daughter, Sue, is awkard in the extreme but the soul of an optimistic good nature.  Her older brother is every teen parent's model of apathy and cynicism.  He could be the poster boy of the teenage years. The actor playing Mike the father also does a good job.  He and Heaton mesh believably as a couple.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nice to be reminded that comedy can still be funny without being vulgar, stupid or elitist (or all three).  Season two, so far, is hit and miss for 'The Middle' but season one is pretty much one gem after another.  Young master Brick and sweet Sue are my favorite characters, but the whole ensemble is good.  Patricia Heaton's character is a bit over the top at times (written intentionally that way).  She is certainly still one spicy tamale though...hard to believe she just turned 53!
summary: One of the best shows on TV

reviewText: "The Middle" has always been a favorite in my house, mainly because my family has experienced the many complications of the Heck family. While I understand some critics calling the series the most realistic depiction of a family since "Roseanne," "The Middle" is full of warm moments, and does not rely on white trash humor to please its fans. I know that the third season will be just as enjoyable, and I hope many tune in to the series that redefines what it means to be a family in this hectic day and age. Patricia Heaton once said in an interview that many people dub "The Middle," "one of the funniest shows on TV, that you probably aren't watching." At least I, along with all the other fans, know the brilliance of this under-appreciated series, destined to be a classic someday. Be sure to also pick-up the second season set, which continues the misadventures of this wonderfully flawed family.

reviewText: This is one of those great sleeper shows that seems to live in the shadow of other shows on the air - mainlyModern Family: The Complete First Seasonwhich has been one of ABC's crown jewels.  I am glad that ABC moved it to the front of their line-up and it is finally getting the recognition it deserves.I was introduced to this show through a lunch conversation with my sister.  She was laughing hysterically as she explained the various characters (example, whispering to herself when describing "Brick").  The show sounded interesting and I had always loved Patricia Heaton inEverybody Loves Raymond: The Complete Series, so I had to find this little advertised show and give it a watch.It was LOVE at first sight!  Even though I hadn't had the background of the show, I saw one or two episodes from season 2 and fell in love with the wonderful cast of characters.  Brick, Sue, Frankie, Mike and Axl.  A perfect blend of characters, the show is gut-wrenchingly funny.After seeing 1-2 episodes I quickly ordered the first season on DVD so that I could catch up.  This is one of the few shows where "out of the box" the series is funny.  The first episode sets the framework up beautifully and does not leave the viewer wanting anything except more episodes.  We watch these over and over and are waiting with baited breath for season 2 to hit DVD.If you want a refreshingly funny comedy that is family friendly, this is it.  The characters are clever and funny.  I am hoping this series lasts many, many seasons.  It's a winner!
summary: Funny to the core.  A refreshingly, funny show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Middle is by far the tv series (past and present) that provides the truest glimpse into what family life is really like and really all about. Unlike "Rosanne" which is parent-centric, the Middle has a perfect balance between adult/parenting perspective and child/being parented perspective. Parenting, even mediocre parenting is really, really hard and at times seemingly impossible. And being under the control and restrictions of parents, even ones who love you and take care of your needs, is annoying and often infuriating.I love in this show how the kids are front and center, not tucked away to appear only when convenient to the storyline. There is no getting away from them. And how the parents are fallible human beings who make mistakes, lots of them. This show hits the mark again and again on stuff that we've done, said, or has happened in our household, and it's quite therapeutic to know we are not alone.The characters and acting are exceptional, the writers are insightful and never seems to run out of material, and the delivery is hilarious. The chemistry between the five main characters (and several minor characters) is great. I love how each episode stands on its own but weaves in plots and happenings from previous shows. There are also cameos of very famous actors playing out of character, e.g., in seasons 1&2 Betty White plays the cruel librarian and Brooke Shields the unkempt white-trashy neighbor hahahaha.As a major bonus I and my almost 16 year old now have "our show." We have worked our way through Season one (my favorite season) and are two discs into season two. If you like me got onto the Middle bandwagon late in the game you are in for a treat.
summary: Must see for anyone considering parenthood

reviewText: This show is by far the best show (of any category) on TV at this time and has become one of my all time favorite shows. It is so well written and directed. The characters are quirky but relatable and very likable. The show has heart and although we follow the characters through a comedic half hour of trials and tribulations each show always ends on a positive and hopeful note. I just received the DVD of season one and have almost finished the entire season laughing my head off with a big smile on my face the entire time. Not to pit this against other shows but it seems this show has been overshadowed by that other family show that airs on the same night--but this one is sooooo much better! Kudos to the cast and creators such a wonderful show. I hope it remains on air for many seasons to come.Regarding the DVD itself, it is great quality enhanced for wide screen TV's. There are a few bonus features as well as deleted scenes for many of the episodes. If you like this show the DVD is worth having.

reviewText: A few years ago, Modern Family garnered all the attention as the next great American family comedy. I bought into the hype and watched that show week after week and waited for the laughs that never came. With all due apologies to the fans of that show, it has never made me laugh once. It tries hard. Maybe too hard and that is the problem.About the same time, The Middle arrived and it was not exactly considered 'must see' tv, so I never watched until this week. I downloaded a few episodes and loved them so much I had to buy the entire first season. It is utterly brilliant how funny this show is. The cast is terrific and they turn everyday events into moments of hilarity that few shows have ever attained. I am not exaggerating when I say there are more genuine laugh out loud moments in the pilot than I experienced in the entire first season of Modern Family. But The Middle is not politically correct and that is why it not getting all the attention.And the moments of family bonding work because they arrive unexpectedly and not overly done. It reminds me in a way of MASH and how they used comedy so wonderfully and then tossed in a moment of great drama.And I have to give special mention to Eden Sher, who plays Sue Heck. She pulls off an amazing trick in creating someone who is wholly original in just about every way. Some will draw comparisons to Blossom from NBC many years ago but no. They may have a resemblance physically but Eden is far superior as a comedic actress.I don't follow the Emmys so I was shocked when I looked and it has not even been nominated but Modern Family has won a few times? Crazy.If you want a series that will make you laugh, smile and just feel good, this is it. It towers over the likes of Modern Family.Ten years from now, Modern Family will be one of those series that has all the hardware but will be mostly forgotten(a lot of 'successful' series are that way) but this series, The Middle, will become like Arrested Development, a show not appreciated in its own time, both brilliant comedies for the ages.

reviewText: The Middle is one of my all-time favorite sit-com's, because the actors are so darn good. The kids are hilarious, without being overly adorable or outrageously obnoxious. The dialogue is top-notch and tremendously funny because it sounds real. The parents are suitably stressed and frustrated, but have actual concern for their kids -- even when they would really rather do things for themselves. Just as in our own lives, "it's all about the little moments," as Patricia Heaton says. Those are the ones that add up to the memories that we all have of family life.If you'd like to laugh along with a family cast of characters that are funny without being snarky or cruel, I really do recommend The Middle.

reviewText: I found this show by accident during the summer repeat season and initially thought it interesting but a little flat.  It wasn't ELR nor even (the cancelled way too early) "Back to You".  It's different from Patricia Heaton's earlier shows, but makes up for the lack of fireworks with a subtle social undercurrent that runs through the episodic plot lines.  Never grating or in your face, you never forget that the Heck family is living the day to day struggle to hang onto a middle class lifestyle that is tragically slipping away from so many in the real world.The title itself is sly and descriptive meaning either middle class, middle age, mid-America or mid-point in Heaton's career depending on how one wants to interpret it.  The plot lines are a little predictable and bland, but  the cast, is more than up to the task of raising the scripts to a higher level than they deserve.  The kids are suitably nutty enough to endear them to viewers without their personalities reaching the cloyingly sweet level.  The quarry closing where "hubby" worked, the kids need to fit in and "Frankie's" daily grind of holding it all together present a charming and realistic sit-com that has great potential to become a staple for years to come.  My only reservations are some of the weaker scripts and whether or not this show will be allowed the time to "blossom".  If ABC has any brains left in it's corporate offices, they'll give it the time.UPDATE:  Fortunately "The Middle" has been given  time to mature and has taken on a "Rosanne for the 21st century" patina which wears pretty well as the ratings seem to be up.  "Mike" is back at work and they've dropped quite a bit of the social commentary and focused on the dysfunctional family story lines which is probably what network TV viewers want to see.  The two younger kids ("Brick"  and "Sue") have emerged as standouts and portray a comic reality not seen in sitcoms since the emergence of Bart Simpson and the Bundy kids 2 decades ago.  Not the greatest comedy ever broadcast, but enjoyable and quirky.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this show!I can't remember when it's on (because I think TV is a wasteland and can never find anything to watch), but I luck into it and I've told scores of people about it---laughing so hard as I describe scenes that are too funny to ever forget.  The writers have a dry sense of humor and sometimes the whole show will build to a single line that will make you laugh out loud.The little kid, Brick, is hysterical---but all the kids are.  The director just pulls out these performances that are incredible, never over the top.  I think it's sort of a shame that Modern Family follows this show because the sense of humor there is more in your face and the kids can be melodramatic.  Which is the exact opposite of The Middle.  The Middle's humor is so subtle and profound, it's possible to miss it if you aren't paying attention.The episode with the oldest son having to care for the baby is beyond hysterical--I think it's the funniest thing I have ever seen.  Beyond hysterical!  (not a spoiler)  When Brick says, "Believe me, I know"---you will hoot, hoot, hoot.  Almost as funny is the one-liner in another episode when the mother talks about cleaning her gun for 29 minutes.The parents are OK on this show.  The mother has some of the best lines and sometimes her timing could be a lot better.  The dad sort of sounds like he has cotton in his mouth and did anyone bother to stand these two people next to each other during casting.  Apparently they realize this because the cover is completely fake---if you take the mother on the cover and move her head down to about three inches above his belt buckle, that's what they REALLY look like side by side.  Seriously.The Thanksgiving episode is also great!  You just have to see this show.  It's a must-see, believe me!!!!!
summary: A MUST-SEE, even if you hate TV!!!!

reviewText: I am a Patricia Heaton fan.  I have enjoyed her work since Everybody Loves Raymond.  I loved the short lived show she did with Kelsey Grammar a couple years ago called "Back to You."  I was so mad when it was cancelled.  Then came "The Middle."  This show is a gem.  I love Brick, the little guy with an inquisitive mind and that oddball way he repeats his comments to himself in a whisper. I love Axel and Sue.  Each kid has their own unique personality.  And Heaton and Neil Flynn are great as the parents.  The stories are quick, smart and endearing.  The focus is family togetherness in a small Indiana town.  I even get a giggle out of the Heck's horribly gawdy decorated home.  But they all love each other and their affection for one another is precious.  I do hope this show stays on for a long time as it is high quality, original and a joy to watch.  It is followed on Wednesday nights by "Modern Family", another great new comedy.  ABC has finally hit two right out the ball park.  I can't wait for their DVD releases.
summary: One of the Best New Shows out there.

reviewText: This is a clean, family friendly show that we absolutely love. They do not sacrifice pure humor for raunchy topics and/or easy, bawdy laughs.If you are looking for a very humorous look on the mundane life of a lower middle class family stuck in the middle of the country, this show is perfect. Frankie's heart of gold and constant attempts to be an adequate mother, with the witty dialogue of her husband, the loving antics of their continually optimistic daughter Sue, the self-centered antagonizing older brother Axle, and the quirks of the youngest, and smartest, Brick make a family dynamic you'll fall in love with.We hope to get all the seasons on DVD, and bought Season One for my mom and mother-in-law for Mother's Day one year. They are now both hooked to this feel-good and hilarious show.
summary: One of the BEST Shows on TV Today

reviewText: This is one of the funniest shows on TV right now.  It is so true to real life, at least in my house.  The show portrays a family of five.  Francis and Mike are the parents.  They have three children, Axl, Sue, and Brick. Axl is the older brother and usually wears boxer shorts. He is sarcastic, lazy, and teases his brother and sister. Sue is the middle daughter. She tries out for everything possible at her school, but she rarely get into the group.  However she is determined to try again and she is very optimistic. Brick is the youngest boy.  He loves books and going to the library!  He also whispers that last word of this sentences to himself.My family looks forward to Wednesday nights so we can watch this show together.  If you are looking for a funny show, give this one a try.  It is so funny!

reviewText: The pilot episode is the reason this apparent clone of "Malcolm In The Middle" got picked up by ABC.  Whoever thought Patricia Heaton could come off looking sexy wearing a pair of red tights and blue underwear--in her fifties?  The only other woman who could have come close would have been Meredith Vieira, who would have been equally suited for the role of Frankie Heck had she decided to hang up her Today Show career a few years earlier.  This show got decidedly different from "Malcolm" as the series wore on, since the small town setting of Orson, Indiana, closely resembles Dog River, Saskatchewan, from the Canadian sitcom "Corner Gas".  A great start to what has been a fixture on ABC's Wednesday comedy block.  FOX is probably wishing they could acquire this and pair it with "Raising Hope" on Tuesday nights, following "Glee".

reviewText: I'm still baffled about this show which fails to get the critics as does Modern Family. Unlike Modern Family, The Middle is more real to me. It's set in Orson, Indiana which is a fictional town where sitcom vets Patricia Heaton (Emmy Winner from Everybody Loves Raymond) plays Frances "Frankie Heck. She should have earned a Best Actress in a Comedy series nomination at least but anyway she runs a household with Mike Heck (played by Scrubs' alum Neil Flynn) who is just perfect casting.Their children include teenage boy Axl (Charlie Dermott) who likes to take off his shirt too much, middle school Sue (Eden Shurr) who never gets respect or attention even in school but her spirit is strong, and there's the youngest son, Brick (Atticus Shaffer) who whispers to himself and reads a lot. Anyway, the show is rounded out by Frankie's workplace. She works at a car dealership with Chris Kattan who plays lonely single guy and her best friend.Sometimes we get great guest stars like Frances Bay who plays Aunt Ginnie (the actress is 90 years old in real life and she's still working.) She deserves kudos. I love the series and the show is funny without trying. The episodes are always unique and special. I wasn't a fan of Malcolm in the Middle or Everybody Loves Raymond or Scrubs but I'm a fan of this show. I think Patricia Heaton really shines as the head of this show's cast. Her character isn't perfect. No Frankie's far from it.The show is more entertaining than any others that night. When everybody talks about Modern Family, I keep wanting to talk and scream about the Middle and I'm disappointed that the Academy hasn't recognized the show's writing, acting, or anything. It's still about the funniest show on television without the awards.
summary: They Should Have Been At Least Nominated for Emmys!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Patricia Heaton's talent was over-shadowed all the years she played second fiddle to Ray Romano.  In The Middle, her talent really has a chance to shine.  She carries the lead amazingly and is the perfect person to do so.  Neil Flynn, who plays her husband on the show, is also the right actor for that part.  He delivers his lines in a funny, typical fatherly way!  Eden Sher, is the teenage daughter, but over-plays her part quite a bit.  Still, she comes across loveable and funny.  Charlie McDermott, the lazy teenage son, also tends to overact, but he, too, still makes you laugh.  And, of course, Atticus Shaffer, playing the youngest son, has a way of stealing your heart and making you want to see more of him.Whoever is responsible for casting does a marvelous job of selecting actors to play the additional characters in the episodes. Watching each one a second time around made me laugh twice as much, because I picked up funny lines I can't believe I missed the first time.  This show has good writers with excellent material, and if you want to laugh - and laugh some more, this is the series to watch.  It is TOO funny for words!
